Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Diazoxide Cardioprotection in Mouse Models of Global Ischemia

Background: Diazoxide, an adenosine triphosphate-sensitive potassium channel opener, is known for its cardioprotective effects. This study aimed to clarify its mechanism of action in cardiac surgery settings.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial involved isolated mouse myocytes and hearts. Myocytes were exposed to Tyrode's solution, hyperkalemic cardioplegia (CPG) ± diazoxide, ± VU591 (Kir1.1 inhibitor), and Tyrode's solution again. Isolated hearts from wild-type, SUR1(−/−), and cardiac knockout renal outer medullary potassium (ROMK) mice were subjected to CPG ± diazoxide before global ischemia and reperfusion. Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed. Investigators were blinded to group assignments.

Results: Myocyte contractility was reduced by CPG but preserved by diazoxide. VU591 negated diazoxide's effect in myocytes. In hearts, diazoxide improved left ventricular function post-ischemia in all mouse types. No adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: The study indicates that SUR1 and ROMK are not involved in diazoxide-mediated cardioprotection, suggesting independent mechanisms in myocytes and hearts.

Trial registration: Not provided.

Funding: Not specified.
